6aubESniVrUJCCmMfs7gGQ5ciYU2.bio: Jerrell Mardis (@jerrellmardis) is a Google Developer Expert for Android, an Android engineer at Salesforce.com and an organizer for Google Developer Group Chicago West. Through his work as a public speaker and community organizer, Jerrell hopes to help elevate the tech community scene in Chicago. He has been developing apps for Android since Android 2.0 and is passionate about building beautiful and functional Android apps that exceed users' expectations. He is also the creator of the successful transit application, Ride Metra.
6aubESniVrUJCCmMfs7gGQ5ciYU2.name: Jerrell Mardis
6aubESniVrUJCCmMfs7gGQ5ciYU2.title: Lead Android Engineer

8DqZcx3zHoOPuTT1MHM493bpfIF3.bio:
Dan has been an Android programmer at Basecamp for 3 years, and prior to that had been working with Java for...a long time. 

He's always enjoyed Android development, but working with Kotlin over the last two years has rocketed that enthusiasm to a whole new level. The Android community has been instrumental to his work and career, and he's a big believer in paying that forward.

Outside of work, he's an avid Dad üë¥, donut aficionado üç©, pizza lover üçï, and emoji enthusiast üòâ.
8DqZcx3zHoOPuTT1MHM493bpfIF3.name: Dan Kim
8DqZcx3zHoOPuTT1MHM493bpfIF3.title: Programmer

OrviRlXkHySeGk9LorOCrV6kCwI3.bio: I'm the Android developer at Pixite where I work on Pigment, and I'm also a Google Developer Expert.  I've been developing Android apps since 2009 and love working on anything fun, usually graphics related.
OrviRlXkHySeGk9LorOCrV6kCwI3.name: Ryan Harter
OrviRlXkHySeGk9LorOCrV6kCwI3.title: Android Developer

-L1ZYz-3uEBPZf0LPoPI.abstract: Changes in the Android world happen so rapidly. There isn‚Äôt one right way to do something and documentation doesn‚Äôt always keep up. And sometimes you may feel that you can‚Äôt keep up. So how do you as a developer - keep up with an ever changing field, make sure your workplace and community catches up, make sure you are using the right tools to make beautiful apps a reality, and work with people from design, product and/or marketing who may not have worked on the Android ecosystem before? Let‚Äôs talk about how you can be an Android developer who brings teams and communities together.

comments.KJ17IrpIISTfjfCufr5rnglWoU53: This is a great topic for keynote

-L1ZYz-3uEBPZf0LPoPI.notes: I'm interested in giving a keynote and decided to submit this abstract. I have spoken at several conferences before and feel that my 7 years of professional experience in the Android world and 3 years of community experience as a GDG co-organizer and conference speaker will help me give a keynote that is applicable to all levels of Android developers. All my previous talks are available at http://www.yprabhu.com/p/speaking.html. Thank you!
-L1ZYz-3uEBPZf0LPoPI.title: Keynote: Being more than an Android developer

-L1Y4_8Wb9Y_bf3AKBTL.abstract:
Architecture Components were announced to much fanfare at Google I/O 2017, as it finally gave Android developers some official guidance on how to architect their applications.  It also gave us tools to make managing lifecycle changes much easier, and to persist data without writing lots of annoying SQLite boilerplate code.  By now we‚Äôve all read the documentation and tutorials, but how easy is it to use these intriguing new tools in a production application? (Spoiler alert: they‚Äôre pretty helpful)

I developed an app from scratch using all of the new Architecture Components - ViewModels and an MVVM architecture, Room to persist all the local data, and LiveData objects to easily and safely update the UI with automatic lifecycle handling.  Join us as we discuss in detail what it‚Äôs like to use these new Architecture Components in a real world situation - we‚Äôll talk about the problems they solved, the problems they created, and whether or not they‚Äôre the right choice for your next project.
-L1Y4_8Wb9Y_bf3AKBTL.notes:
I was lucky enough to speak at the inaugural Chicago Roboto 2017 and had an incredible experience, and would love the opportunity to speak again in 2018.  I also spoke at the first droidcon Boston in 2017, and have spoken at various Android meetups and tech events around Toronto.

My company should be able to help cover at least some (if not all) of the costs.

Here are some of my previous presentations:

https://news.realm.io/news/android-auto-drive-your-car-use-your-phone-dont-get-hurt/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GeSKaz6PCm4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WNaJlP36I4E
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UsX2ySEKbYw
https://vimeo.com/217597546
https://speakerdeck.com/physphil
-L1Y4_8Wb9Y_bf3AKBTL.title: I Wrote an App Using all of the Architecture Components... And Here‚Äôs How It Turned Out.

-L05aVkr2wuZxr7IWT88.abstract:
Starting out in a new career is scary.  Learning new technologies, navigating company and career goals, staying up-to-date in a constantly changing ecosystem; it can be overwhelming. 

Over the last several years, I‚Äôve learned a number of things (sometimes the hard way) that I‚Äôd love to share with my past self.

In this talk, I‚Äôll share that advice with you. 

We'll explore tips & lessons learned from personal experiences learning Android, starting that 1st professional role, developing your skills, and interacting with the community.
-L05aVkr2wuZxr7IWT88.notes:
This is a topic near and dear to my heart.  I really believe strongly in developing an inclusive community that includes helping new students/professionals feel welcome, and helping them understand that it's absolutely normal to feel lost and overwhelmed at times.

I've shared a little about my experiences before, https://medium.com/udacity/my-year-with-udacitys-android-nanodegree-e8dab119b085
I'm organizing a meetup for Udacity students/alumni that will discuss some of these same topics as well: https://www.meetup.com/Udacious-Seattle/
-L05aVkr2wuZxr7IWT88.title: Tips From the Time Machine: Things I Wish I'd Known When Starting a Career as an Android dev

-Kyta2X6gvz6tNeIZgyJ.abstract: Working with Android studio Template is fun, productive and efficient developing application in groups. It saves the developer time and facilitates to follow the common coding conventions throughout the organization with ease. By creating efficient templates, developer can focus on other business logic, requirements and architecture rather spending time on doing repetitive tasks all over the day. Yeah! Android Studio Templates are user-friendly which provides cool UI and can be customized according to the industry standards by just editing the templates class files.
-Kyta2X6gvz6tNeIZgyJ.notes:
Blogs on Template Creation : 

1. https://medium.com/androidstarters/mastering-android-studio-templates-ed8fdd98cb78
2. https://medium.com/androidstarters/creating-android-studio-ide-template-for-recyclerviews-a8b6d4925f3f

Github Repository:

1. https://github.com/TakeoffAndroid/RecyclerViewTemplate
2. https://github.com/TakeoffAndroid/MaterialTabsTemplate
-Kyta2X6gvz6tNeIZgyJ.title: Mastering Android Studio Template Creation

-L-sGVYC5vHBmdl-2apa.abstract: ConstraintLayout 2.0 will be introduced early 2018, with many new features. This talk will present those new features and concepts. If possible, we would like the abstract to be updated once the release is out.
-L-sGVYC5vHBmdl-2apa.notes: John Hoford hoford@google.com will be my co-presenter
-L-sGVYC5vHBmdl-2apa.title: ConstraintLayout 2.0

-L-2S4rWWRVi2OlUEpRR.abstract:
Mark Allison (author of https://blog.stylingandroid,com) has a deep love of VectorDrawable. He has spoken at conferences about how to construct and Animate them in his talk entitled "Vector All The Things".

In this all new talk, Mark will look at some of the features which have been added to VectorDrawable and its sibling AnimatedVectorDrawable since they first appeared in Android Lollipop 5.0 (API 21). There will be a dive in to fill windings which can cause some baffling rendering oddities, yet can be quite simple to fix once you recognise that fill windings are the cause; There will also be a look at the recently added gradient support; And, of course, there will be plenty of tricks and tips to help with your creation of fabulous VectorDrawables, and amazing Animations.
-L-2S4rWWRVi2OlUEpRR.notes: I will require flights and accommodation to be covered, but may be able to receive some financial assistance from Google toward this (for Chicago Roboto last year, Google paid for my flights, and the organisers only needed to cover my accommodation). However last year was complicated because it was left late, and flight prices has increased, and Google's budget had been largely used up. Therefore the earlier that you could confirm whether I have had a talk accepted, the more likely it is that I shall be able to get some financial assistance from Google.
-L-2S4rWWRVi2OlUEpRR.title: wow. very vector. such love

-L0R7e0jvXReu7pzpOth.abstract:
ADB is maybe one of the most used tools by the Android developers. But it is for sure the less known. 
If you ever wondered how ADB is working? Why is it faster now? How Android Studio is using it under the hood? Why my ADB server is killed sometimes? And by the way, what this server is about? This talk is made for you. 

I spent several weeks diving into the ADB source code and I learned interesting things about this project, its history, the internals, the interaction with the developers tools, ... It's time for me to share this with you. 

Here is an outline of the presentation: 
- How ADB works (the big picture) 
- Some ADB commands you maybe never heard about 
- The history of the project 
- The ADB Internals (the ADB protocols, the structure of the software)
- How development tools are using ADB?
-L0R7e0jvXReu7pzpOth.notes: I already gave the talk at Droidcon NYC (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dzx81sAKylg) and Paris Android User Group (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLNsa1Kjve8).
-L0R7e0jvXReu7pzpOth.title: ADB, Break On Through To the Other Side

-L1DYvhOuHCYofznm459.abstract: RxJava is an incredibly nice library that lets us take our data on a journey through network calls, databases, UI threads and background threads. But how do we actually achieve concurrency, responsibly? Are we testing it to ensure our own sanity? Are we protecting ourselves against race conditions? Is flatMap() and merge() enough? Demonstrating an understanding in creating and testing Rx streams helps us to achieve concurrency in this powerful library.
-L1DYvhOuHCYofznm459.notes:
Hi Chicago Roboto! I'm currently an Android Developer at Yello.co. I love working with the RxJava framework and how easy it's made our Android app to maintain.

I really want to do a talk on concurrency with this widely-popular framework because, as a junior developer learning all of the pitfalls of concurrency, it's opened my eyes to all the ways we can shoot ourselves in the foot. I wrote this article (https://proandroiddev.com/testing-concurrency-in-rxjava-831804a9e526) in Pro Android Dev to contribute some of what I've learned, but I realized I could do an entire talk on the subject!

I'm hoping to cover a more broad approach to concurrency and leave viewers with a more rounded-out view of how things happen in the framework.

I've never spoken at a conference (at the time of the writing of this proposal) but in January I will have done a talk called Privet Kotlin at Windy City Dev Fest. Here's a link: https://windycity.devfest.io/sessions/-L0GMdpLLWSmT68IqRkO
-L1DYvhOuHCYofznm459.title: Achieving Concurrency in RxJava

-KysBHqCHfvCEV6OaTnP.abstract: Are you one of the numerous developers who wants to implement Espresso testing but hasn't? Perhaps it's for one of the common reasons - not enough expertise or time, it feels like a daunting task, or it feels downright tedious. I have personally felt each of those things. All of that changed once I learned about the robot pattern. In this talk we'll go over how the robot pattern helps you write cleaner and more maintainable tests, as well as how it can be leveraged for better test reporting. You'll walk away with an understanding of how to write tests much more thoroughly and efficiently so that it can easily become a natural part of your build process, and not shoved in the back log and left untouched.
-KysBHqCHfvCEV6OaTnP.notes: A short blog post I've written on this topic, though I plan for the talk to go more in depth - https://androidessence.com/android/leveraging-the-robot-pattern-for-espresso-tests/
-KysBHqCHfvCEV6OaTnP.title: Espresso Patronum: The Magic Of The Robot Pattern

-L1ZrO-T1SS0UzjrX4Gs.abstract:
Even if you‚Äôre brand new to Kotlin, you might know that you can right-click any Java file and convert it automatically. Score! But wait, what are all these ‚Äú!!‚Äù and why is the code littered with ‚Äú?‚Äù. Sure, the code compiles, but how do you make the code not just compile but follow best practices? How do you get closer to making your code idiomatic?

In the third part of our series on learning the cool and idiomatic parts of Kotlin, we're going to look at some intermediate Kotlin topics. We're going to look at how inlining can improve the performance on higher-order functions as well as allow us to take advantage of type reification. Then we'll take a look at how delegation can help us write dryer, more efficient, and more interesting properties with less boiler plate. Finally, we'll dive into the magical world of asynchronous programming the Kotlin way with coroutines.
-L1ZrO-T1SS0UzjrX4Gs.notes:
My co-presenter will be Christina Lee.

Both of us spoke at Chicago Roboto last year.
Huyen Tue Dao, "Cool ConstraintLayout": https://youtu.be/Xx4aRI3oQbM
Christina Lee, "Retrofitting Retrofit"
-L1ZrO-T1SS0UzjrX4Gs.title: The Road to Kotlintown III: Delegate 95 to Coroutine 66

-L-G9e3es-COhq0M650L.abstract:
Tofus (‚ñ°) are representations used when a specific character (like an Emoji) cannot be displayed. You have seen them, and so your users.

Thanks to EmojiCompat, now Android developers have a way to provide Emoji compatibility for older devices, but does it solve all the issues developers have with Emoji? 

Have you wondered why Twitter counts characters differently depending on the Emoji? Or how gender and skin tone Emoji modifiers work? How can I have a similar functionality as Slack on my app with custom Emoji? Do all your users see the same Emoji?

On this talk, you will learn about the different pitfalls developers face when working with Emoji, like code points, the Fitzpatrick modifiers and short-names, you will learn how to use EmojiCompat and I will show you alternatives to it.

In this talk you will learn:
- What are the problems developers face with Emoji
- How Emoji works
- How to use EmojiCompat including dynamic font downloading
- What is EmojiCompat not solving, and what can you do
- What alternatives are there to EmojiCompat
- ..and of course everything with Kotlin!

After this talk, you will be an Emoji expert, no longer afraid of showing ‚ñ° (tofu) to your users!
-L-G9e3es-COhq0M650L.notes:
This will be an improved and extended version of the talk I gave on the Berlindroid meetup event back in summer. Here‚Äôs a summary on how the talk went: https://medium.com/@Miqubel/talk-no-more-taming-emoji-on-android-c4f3825e510c 

This talk will include as well code samples for the attendees in a GitHub repo.

I am very interested in this topic: At work we used to have a custom solution for displaying Emoji until EmojiCompat came out, and we used to do a lots of tricks to support the latest Unicode Emoji specs, since we are a social network that uses Emoji a lot. We are early adopters of EmojiCompat, using it since it‚Äôs beta release.

I think this is an interesting topic that usually doesn‚Äôt get enough attention but can affect anyone who is dealing with user generated content.

I will also be giving a talk in February on the DroidKaigi conference in Tokyo, and I‚Äôve also given two talks at the Berlin DevFest. All of them about different topics. You can check my speaker deck: https://speakerdeck.com/miquelbeltran If you need more references, my Medium articles have been published both at AndroidWeekly and KotlinWeekly
-L-G9e3es-COhq0M650L.title: No More ‚ñ° ‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää Mastering Emoji on Android

-L1aXPSRjrfFiFS-sksm.abstract:
Although it is buzzing nowadays, machine learning is still a stranger to many of us.
However, worry not! Making your app smarter has just become wayyy easier with the new TensorFlow for Android.
On this talk, we‚Äôll get to know some basic ML concepts and usages, and create our first machine learning Android app using TensorFlow!
-L1aXPSRjrfFiFS-sksm.title: Who‚Äôs afraid of Machine Learning? First steps with TensorFlow for Android.

-L1Zag9BgNhutvZebqO8.abstract:
Picasso is a powerful image downloading and caching library for Android but since its launch in 2013, other libraries have improved or entered the scene and new requirements have come up.  

In this talk, we‚Äôll:
* Dig into the internals of Picasso works
* Compare and contrast to other image libraries
* Discuss latest improvements as we push to 3.0
* ...and more!

You‚Äôll learn to efficiently work with different image formats across millions of devices!
-L1Zag9BgNhutvZebqO8.title: Rinsing the Brush: Picasso 3.0

-L1453alPCtSTM9843Jy.abstract:
We have had many talks and blog posts on Dagger till now and people have done a great job at explaining it's various concepts. Dagger is something which has become a part of our coding lives now. Yet, from time-to-time we still find ourselves lost while dealing with ‚ÄúThe Dahaka (an infinite storm in an ocean of Providers, Factories, Builders, MemberInjectors, DoubleChecks, Lazy, Producers...)‚Äù. 

Starting to learn about Dagger? Start by creating a Module and a Component. Add a Singleton scope to it. 
Dependencies getting out of hand? Create another dependent component.
Creating a dependent component? You should create another scope!! 
Create a subcomponent.
Still alive? Now we present you with Dagger Android and I am sure that it will certainly kill you :P

But wait! What exactly is the relation between a Module and a Component? 

Thankfully! Dagger 2 generates all it‚Äôs code at compile time and we can actually see what‚Äôs going on behind the scenes.

In this talk we will aim to Defeat ‚ÄúThe Dahaka (a storm in the ocean of generated classes)‚Äù. After attending this talk you will get a better sense of what goes on behind the scenes and how to smartly move to Dagger Android  :)
-L1453alPCtSTM9843Jy.notes:
For more information, series ‚ÄúDagger and The Dahaka‚Äù on medium : https://proandroiddev.com/dagger-2-android-defeat-the-dahaka-b1c542233efc

I gave a similar talk at Droidcon Berlin, 2017 https://droidcon.de/en/sessions/dagger-2-android-defeat-dahaka

Demo code : https://github.com/ragdroid/Dahaka
-L1453alPCtSTM9843Jy.title: Dagger 2 Android : Defeat the Dahaka

-KxynTzs-dXn0PCuVJdf.abstract: Writing high-quality path morphing animations for Android is a near impossible task. In order to morph one shape into another, the SVG paths describing the two must be compatible with each other‚Äîthat is, they need to have the same number and type of drawing commands. Unfortunately popular design tools, such as Sketch and Illustrator, do not take this into account, and as a result engineers will often have to spend time tweaking the raw SVGs given to them by designers before they can be morphed. To address this issue, I built a web app called Shape Shifter (https://shapeshifter.design), a tool that helps developers and designers to more easily create path morphing animations for their Android apps. In this talk, I will explain how to use Shape Shifter to create seamless transitions between arbitrary shapes using AnimatedVectorDrawables. I will also explain how Shape Shifter internally uses bioinformatics algorithms in order to auto-generate morphing animations between incompatible shapes, as well as some of the challenges I faced while building the tool.
-KxynTzs-dXn0PCuVJdf.title: In-depth path morphing w/ Shape Shifter

-L1ZPfPC0rO8qTQ3umb3.abstract:
Every day each one of us turns to community contributions to help us become better developers ‚Äî blog posts, open source projects, conference talks, podcasts, and so much more. Can you imagine if these community resources didn‚Äôt exist?!

And while our community is strong today, it‚Äôs healthiest when it continues to grow from a broad set of interests, backgrounds and opinions. That diversity and knowledge to keep our community strong can only come from one place: YOU.

I‚Äôll share my thoughts about how this community has helped me (and others) grow, why that‚Äôs so important, and ultimately why it‚Äôs crucial for all of us to contribute. I‚Äôll discuss five (or so) areas, each with some high level tips to get you started, that we can all contribute to to keep our community strong and healthy.

The Android community has proven to be one of the most welcoming, friendly, helpful, generous groups I‚Äôve ever encountered. Let‚Äôs keep it going!
-L1ZPfPC0rO8qTQ3umb3.title: The future of our community is YOU

ar-core.abstract: Google introduced ARCore for Android in August of last year. This is your opportunity to step in on the ground floor of the developing potential around augmented reality on mobile. We‚Äôll walk through some of the fundamental capabilities, things to avoid, why you might want to use it, and some resources that might be helpful for you.
ar-core.title: Intro to ARCore

2018-04-12.abstract: Changes in the Android world happen so rapidly. There isn‚Äôt one right way to do something and documentation doesn‚Äôt always keep up. And sometimes you may feel that you can‚Äôt keep up. So how do you as a developer - keep up with an ever changing field, make sure your workplace and community catches up, make sure you are using the right tools to make beautiful apps a reality, and work with people from design, product and/or marketing who may not have worked on the Android ecosystem before? Let‚Äôs talk about how you can be an Android developer who brings teams and communities together.

2018-04-12.abstract:
Architecture Components were announced to much fanfare at Google I/O 2017, as it finally gave Android developers some official guidance on how to architect their applications.  It also gave us tools to make managing lifecycle changes much easier, and to persist data without writing lots of annoying SQLite boilerplate code.  By now we‚Äôve all read the documentation and tutorials, but how easy is it to use these intriguing new tools in a production application? (Spoiler alert: they‚Äôre pretty helpful)

I developed an app from scratch using all of the new Architecture Components - ViewModels and an MVVM architecture, Room to persist all the local data, and LiveData objects to easily and safely update the UI with automatic lifecycle handling.  Join us as we discuss in detail what it‚Äôs like to use these new Architecture Components in a real world situation - we‚Äôll talk about the problems they solved, the problems they created, and whether or not they‚Äôre the right choice for your next project.
2018-04-12.notes:
I was lucky enough to speak at the inaugural Chicago Roboto 2017 and had an incredible experience, and would love the opportunity to speak again in 2018.  I also spoke at the first droidcon Boston in 2017, and have spoken at various Android meetups and tech events around Toronto.

Starting out in a new career is scary.  Learning new technologies, navigating company and career goals, staying up-to-date in a constantly changing ecosystem; it can be overwhelming.

2018-04-12.abstract:
ADB is maybe one of the most used tools by the Android developers. But it is for sure the less known. 
If you ever wondered how ADB is working? Why is it faster now? How Android Studio is using it under the hood? Why my ADB server is killed sometimes? And by the way, what this server is about? This talk is made for you. 

I spent several weeks diving into the ADB source code and I learned interesting things about this project, its history, the internals, the interaction with the developers tools, ... It's time for me to share this with you. 

Here is an outline of the presentation: 
- How ADB works (the big picture) 
- Some ADB commands you maybe never heard about 
- The history of the project 
- The ADB Internals (the ADB protocols, the structure of the software)
- How development tools are using ADB?
2018-04-12.notes: I already gave the talk at Droidcon NYC (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dzx81sAKylg) and Paris Android User Group (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLNsa1Kjve8).
2018-04-12.title: ADB, Break On Through To the Other Side

2018-04-12.abstract: RxJava is an incredibly nice library that lets us take our data on a journey through network calls, databases, UI threads and background threads. But how do we actually achieve concurrency, responsibly? Are we testing it to ensure our own sanity? Are we protecting ourselves against race conditions? Is flatMap() and merge() enough? Demonstrating an understanding in creating and testing Rx streams helps us to achieve concurrency in this powerful library.
2018-04-12.notes:
Hi Chicago Roboto! I'm currently an Android Developer at Yello.co. I love working with the RxJava framework and how easy it's made our Android app to maintain.

I really want to do a talk on concurrency with this widely-popular framework because, as a junior developer learning all of the pitfalls of concurrency, it's opened my eyes to all the ways we can shoot ourselves in the foot. I wrote this article (https://proandroiddev.com/testing-concurrency-in-rxjava-831804a9e526) in Pro Android Dev to contribute some of what I've learned, but I realized I could do an entire talk on the subject!

I'm hoping to cover a more broad approach to concurrency and leave viewers with a more rounded-out view of how things happen in the framework.

I've never spoken at a conference (at the time of the writing of this proposal) but in January I will have done a talk called Privet Kotlin at Windy City Dev Fest. Here's a link: https://windycity.devfest.io/sessions/-L0GMdpLLWSmT68IqRkO
2018-04-12.title: Achieving Concurrency in RxJava

2018-04-12.abstract: Are you one of the numerous developers who wants to implement Espresso testing but hasn't? Perhaps it's for one of the common reasons - not enough expertise or time, it feels like a daunting task, or it feels downright tedious. I have personally felt each of those things. All of that changed once I learned about the robot pattern. In this talk we'll go over how the robot pattern helps you write cleaner and more maintainable tests, as well as how it can be leveraged for better test reporting. You'll walk away with an understanding of how to write tests much more thoroughly and efficiently so that it can easily become a natural part of your build process, and not shoved in the back log and left untouched.
2018-04-12.notes: A short blog post I've written on this topic, though I plan for the talk to go more in depth - https://androidessence.com/android/leveraging-the-robot-pattern-for-espresso-tests/
2018-04-12.title: Espresso Patronum: The Magic Of The Robot Pattern

2018-04-13.abstract:
Even if you‚Äôre brand new to Kotlin, you might know that you can right-click any Java file and convert it automatically. Score! But wait, what are all these ‚Äú!!‚Äù and why is the code littered with ‚Äú?‚Äù. Sure, the code compiles, but how do you make the code not just compile but follow best practices? How do you get closer to making your code idiomatic?

In the third part of our series on learning the cool and idiomatic parts of Kotlin, we're going to look at some intermediate Kotlin topics. We're going to look at how inlining can improve the performance on higher-order functions as well as allow us to take advantage of type reification. Then we'll take a look at how delegation can help us write dryer, more efficient, and more interesting properties with less boiler plate. Finally, we'll dive into the magical world of asynchronous programming the Kotlin way with coroutines.
2018-04-13.notes:
My co-presenter will be Christina Lee.

Both of us spoke at Chicago Roboto last year.
Huyen Tue Dao, "Cool ConstraintLayout": https://youtu.be/Xx4aRI3oQbM
Christina Lee, "Retrofitting Retrofit"
2018-04-13.title: The Road to Kotlintown III: Delegate 95 to Coroutine 66

2018-04-13.abstract:
Tofus (‚ñ°) are representations used when a specific character (like an Emoji) cannot be displayed. You have seen them, and so your users.

Thanks to EmojiCompat, now Android developers have a way to provide Emoji compatibility for older devices, but does it solve all the issues developers have with Emoji? 

Have you wondered why Twitter counts characters differently depending on the Emoji? Or how gender and skin tone Emoji modifiers work? How can I have a similar functionality as Slack on my app with custom Emoji? Do all your users see the same Emoji?

On this talk, you will learn about the different pitfalls developers face when working with Emoji, like code points, the Fitzpatrick modifiers and short-names, you will learn how to use EmojiCompat and I will show you alternatives to it.

In this talk you will learn:
- What are the problems developers face with Emoji
- How Emoji works
- How to use EmojiCompat including dynamic font downloading
- What is EmojiCompat not solving, and what can you do
- What alternatives are there to EmojiCompat
- ..and of course everything with Kotlin!

After this talk, you will be an Emoji expert, no longer afraid of showing ‚ñ° (tofu) to your users!
2018-04-13.notes:
This will be an improved and extended version of the talk I gave on the Berlindroid meetup event back in summer. Here‚Äôs a summary on how the talk went: https://medium.com/@Miqubel/talk-no-more-taming-emoji-on-android-c4f3825e510c 

This talk will include as well code samples for the attendees in a GitHub repo.

I am very interested in this topic: At work we used to have a custom solution for displaying Emoji until EmojiCompat came out, and we used to do a lots of tricks to support the latest Unicode Emoji specs, since we are a social network that uses Emoji a lot. We are early adopters of EmojiCompat, using it since it‚Äôs beta release.

I think this is an interesting topic that usually doesn‚Äôt get enough attention but can affect anyone who is dealing with user generated content.

I will also be giving a talk in February on the DroidKaigi conference in Tokyo, and I‚Äôve also given two talks at the Berlin DevFest. All of them about different topics. You can check my speaker deck: https://speakerdeck.com/miquelbeltran If you need more references, my Medium articles have been published both at AndroidWeekly and KotlinWeekly
2018-04-13.title: No More ‚ñ° ‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää Mastering Emoji on Android

2018-04-13.abstract:
Although it is buzzing nowadays, machine learning is still a stranger to many of us.
However, worry not! Making your app smarter has just become wayyy easier with the new TensorFlow for Android.
On this talk, we‚Äôll get to know some basic ML concepts and usages, and create our first machine learning Android app using TensorFlow!
2018-04-13.title: Who‚Äôs afraid of Machine Learning? First steps with TensorFlow for Android.

2018-04-13.abstract:
Picasso is a powerful image downloading and caching library for Android but since its launch in 2013, other libraries have improved or entered the scene and new requirements have come up.  

In this talk, we‚Äôll:
* Dig into the internals of Picasso works
* Compare and contrast to other image libraries
* Discuss latest improvements as we push to 3.0
* ...and more!

You‚Äôll learn to efficiently work with different image formats across millions of devices!
2018-04-13.title: Rinsing the Brush: Picasso 3.0

2018-04-13.abstract:
We have had many talks and blog posts on Dagger till now and people have done a great job at explaining it's various concepts. Dagger is something which has become a part of our coding lives now. Yet, from time-to-time we still find ourselves lost while dealing with ‚ÄúThe Dahaka (an infinite storm in an ocean of Providers, Factories, Builders, MemberInjectors, DoubleChecks, Lazy, Producers...)‚Äù. 

Starting to learn about Dagger? Start by creating a Module and a Component. Add a Singleton scope to it. 
Dependencies getting out of hand? Create another dependent component.
Creating a dependent component? You should create another scope!! 
Create a subcomponent.
Still alive? Now we present you with Dagger Android and I am sure that it will certainly kill you :P

But wait! What exactly is the relation between a Module and a Component? 

Thankfully! Dagger 2 generates all it‚Äôs code at compile time and we can actually see what‚Äôs going on behind the scenes.

In this talk we will aim to Defeat ‚ÄúThe Dahaka (a storm in the ocean of generated classes)‚Äù. After attending this talk you will get a better sense of what goes on behind the scenes and how to smartly move to Dagger Android  :)
2018-04-13.notes:
For more information, series ‚ÄúDagger and The Dahaka‚Äù on medium : https://proandroiddev.com/dagger-2-android-defeat-the-dahaka-b1c542233efc

I gave a similar talk at Droidcon Berlin, 2017 https://droidcon.de/en/sessions/dagger-2-android-defeat-dahaka

Demo code : https://github.com/ragdroid/Dahaka
2018-04-13.title: Dagger 2 Android : Defeat the Dahaka

2018-04-13.abstract: Writing high-quality path morphing animations for Android is a near impossible task. In order to morph one shape into another, the SVG paths describing the two must be compatible with each other‚Äîthat is, they need to have the same number and type of drawing commands. Unfortunately popular design tools, such as Sketch and Illustrator, do not take this into account, and as a result engineers will often have to spend time tweaking the raw SVGs given to them by designers before they can be morphed. To address this issue, I built a web app called Shape Shifter (https://shapeshifter.design), a tool that helps developers and designers to more easily create path morphing animations for their Android apps. In this talk, I will explain how to use Shape Shifter to create seamless transitions between arbitrary shapes using AnimatedVectorDrawables. I will also explain how Shape Shifter internally uses bioinformatics algorithms in order to auto-generate morphing animations between incompatible shapes, as well as some of the challenges I faced while building the tool.
2018-04-13.title: In-depth path morphing w/ Shape Shifter

2018-04-13.abstract:
Every day each one of us turns to community contributions to help us become better developers ‚Äî blog posts, open source projects, conference talks, podcasts, and so much more. Can you imagine if these community resources didn‚Äôt exist?!

And while our community is strong today, it‚Äôs healthiest when it continues to grow from a broad set of interests, backgrounds and opinions. That diversity and knowledge to keep our community strong can only come from one place: YOU.

I‚Äôll share my thoughts about how this community has helped me (and others) grow, why that‚Äôs so important, and ultimately why it‚Äôs crucial for all of us to contribute. I‚Äôll discuss five (or so) areas, each with some high level tips to get you started, that we can all contribute to to keep our community strong and healthy.

The Android community has proven to be one of the most welcoming, friendly, helpful, generous groups I‚Äôve ever encountered. Let‚Äôs keep it going!
2018-04-13.title: The future of our community is YOU

2018-04-13.abstract: Google introduced ARCore for Android in August of last year. This is your opportunity to step in on the ground floor of the developing potential around augmented reality on mobile. We‚Äôll walk through some of the fundamental capabilities, things to avoid, why you might want to use it, and some resources that might be helpful for you.
2018-04-13.title: Intro to ARCore

ng4L290T54Q3WsqGwvS3e1TIiDG3.bio: Yash Prabhu currently leads the Android team at Warner Bros. Digital Labs. She has spoken at several meetups and industry conferences over the past three years. In her spare time, she volunteers at local tech groups as a teaching assistant, organizer and mentor. She currently co-organizes Google Developer Groups Philly and is a former DevOpsDays Philly organizer. She is also the recipient of Tech In Motion Philly's Best Tech Manager 2017 Timmy award.

Mark writes a technical blog (http://blog.stylingandroid.com) which focuses on Android UI/UX topics, but often covers more general Android development techniques.
